title: 109_hr4804
content: The title of the act is the "FHA Manufactured Housing Loan Modernization Act of 2006". The purpose of the act is to provide findings and purposes related to manufactured housing loans. The Congress finds that manufactured housing is crucial for low- and moderate-income families in the US, the FHA title I insurance program is important for manufactured home loans, the market is experiencing a downturn leading to a lack of private lending, and the FHA program has historically provided stability during such times. The FHA title I insurance program for manufactured housing loans has not been adjusted for inflation since 1992, resulting in a lack of financing options for low- and moderate-income homebuyers. The Act aims to provide adequate funding and modernize the program to enhance participation. The Act aims to adjust low loan limits for title I manufactured home loan insurance to reflect cost increases since 1992 and index the limits to inflation to enhance participation in Ginnie Mae and private lending markets. SEC. 3 amends the National Housing Act to allow exceptions for manufactured homes. SEC. 4 addresses insurance benefits. The National Housing Act is amended to provide insurance benefits for manufactured housing loans executed under the FHA Manufactured Housing Loan Modernization Act of 2006. The validity of insurance contracts for financial institutions is conclusive and incontestable, except for fraud. The amendment applies to loans registered or endorsed for insurance after the enactment of the Act, with exceptions for fraud or misrepresentation by the institution. SEC. 5. MAXIMUM LOAN LIMITS. The National Housing Act is amended to increase dollar amounts for various clauses and subparagraphs, with adjustments made for inflation. Additionally, annual indexing provisions are added to the Act. The National Housing Act is amended to include annual indexing of manufactured housing loans based on price data collected by the Census Bureau. Technical and conforming changes are also made to the Act. The National Housing Act is amended to include annual indexing of manufactured housing loans based on price data collected by the Census Bureau. Additionally, the Secretary is required to annually increase dollar amount limitations in certain subparagraphs in accordance with an established index. SEC. 6. INSURANCE PREMIUMS. Subsection (f) of section 2 of the National Housing Act is amended to include premium charges for manufactured home loans. The borrower is required to pay a single premium payment at the time of the loan, not exceeding 2.25 percent of the original insured principal obligation, and annual premium payments during the loan term. Premium charges for manufactured home loans are limited to 1.0 percent of the remaining insured principal balance, established to maintain a negative credit subsidy for the program. The Secretary may increase premium payment limitations above set percentages to maintain a negative credit subsidy for manufactured home loans. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. The National Housing Act is amended to remove specific dates and grant the Secretary authority to handle and dispose of property as deemed necessary. The Secretary has the authority to handle and dispose of property as necessary, including pursuing collection of claims and rights related to insurance payments. The Secretary has the authority to handle property and insurance payments, including unpaid premiums. Contracts for hazard insurance or services under $25,000 are exempt from certain regulations. Delegation of authority to execute property-related documents is allowed. The Secretary can delegate the power to exercise title without a formal delegation of power or power of attorney. The Secretary may choose to delegate this power to any appointed officer or agent at their discretion. SEC. 8. REVISION OF UNDERWRITING CRITERIA. The Secretary will establish underwriting criteria for loans related to manufactured housing to ensure financial soundness of the program. This must be done within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will revise underwriting criteria for a program related to manufactured housing within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The House of Representatives passed the Act on July 25, 2006. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
